title: American Cop In Canada Wishes He Had His Gun Because...

comments.text:

spend their lives and careers being suspicious. As for me, I ignore other 
nearby people too much.

have guns."

You are the mental person, Mr. Cenk.
.﻿

comments.author: Marc st-maurice

comments.text:
Americans may live in fear and loathing of their fellow neighbours or 
citizens, but most Canadians will strike up a conversation with anyone, 
especially if they think you're from away, visiting Canada.
We'd like to know where you're from, what you think of the place, what 
sights you've seen, maybe make some sight-seeing suggestions... heck you 
might even get lucky and we buy you lunch and a beer if you're friendly 
back. You may even make new friends for a lifetime.
We don't grow up living in fear of strangers asking friendly questions as 
to whether we've been to the Stampede or not.
Small dick assholes like this American police officer Walt Wawra of 
Kalamazoo, Michigan can stay home--I'm sorry you felt threatened (and 
cowardly not having a gun by your side) by the innocent questions of 
whether you and your wife had enjoyed the sights of the Calgary Stampede.
People like you are what is wrong with this world.

......Just had to repost this cause it's so damn good.﻿

comments.author: Laurena Smith

comments.text:
Published on Aug 9, 2012
"Walt Wawra, a police officer from Kalamazoo, Michigan, was vacationing in 
Calgary, Alberta, with his wife Debbie when he encountered a situation that 
made him reach for his off-duty handgun. But the weapon wasn't there 
because he had been told he has "no need to carry one in Canada." So he 
fired a letter to the Calgary Herald instead to complain about his 
inability to protect his family from the city's riff raff...".* ﻿

comments.author: Linamar

comments.text:
I have read most of the comments on here and it is so funny how people can 
be so ignorant. Yes Canada is a beautiful place and our rules are different 
from the united states or other countries. But I can say this at least we 
help those who need it in other places, We give food, clothes and other 
things to places that need it, as well as try and be a peaceful country. 
Yes there can be some jerks out there but what place don't have them. We 
like to keep our wildlife free and safe what's wrong with that? Maybe we 
don't want to have animals to become extinct.. Umm like the bald eagle 
which is not a very populated animal. But in Canada we try to keep them 
safe so they can produce more. We don't enforce having people carry weapons 
on them walking down the street like some places cause it just causes more 
problems then anything, there are people out there that are nuts and would 
shoot up a whole town if they could. Look up murderers there's a lot of 
that in places where they can have a gun (no license required). But I have 
to say this for the Canadians and Americans.. I am sad to see how you can 
be so mean to one another and discriminate against each other when you have 
no idea yourselves how other countries are or people when you never got to 
see it for yourselves.. We are one as a world but no one sees that and 
thinks the worst of one another. It sickens me to see how people can be 
such bullies or racist to one another and you can say you are not but I 
read differently on here..﻿
comments.author: Samantha Sewell

comments.text:
This cop is clearly delusional. As a police officer it is, or at least 
should be part of your duty to be able to read people and be able to tell 
weather or not they are posing a threat or not. Clearly these people where 
not, and just simply asking if he went to the rodeo or not, which any 
person in Calgary would recommend going to if you haven't. 

And I will state for the obvious reasons, we have our good and bad here in 
Canada, just like any other county, perhaps maybe not as violent, be we do 
still have them. 

Just because someone talks to you doesn't mean they are trying to harm you, 
people are becoming so paranoid and disconnected with each other that we 
can't even tell if people are posing a threat or not. Pay attention keep 
your eyes open, and just use common sense.﻿

comments.author: hugg kiss

comments.text:
I have many American friends.  However, I have also had the argument with 
some of those same friends who have come to my country carrying their 
handguns, regardless of the fact that they know in advance that it is not 
LEGAL!!  "I have the right" said the one.  I said "Fine - but that RIGHT 
stops at the border and does not exist here!"  The other ridicules me and 
asks.. "How about protection?"  I said simply that you don't need it!  He 
was referring to downtown Toronto, where there probably is a cop on every 
street corner.  However, the attitudes of Canadians and Americans are very 
very different.  In Canada, in a difference of opinion, we might punch you 
and you'll get a black eye, possibly.  In the United States, in a 
difference of opinion, somebody will pull a gun and somebody else will 
probably die!  To those Americans who mourn their inability to pack a 
firearm in Canada?... STAY HOME!  Do NOT come here.  We don't want  to 
support you in our jails and certainly don't need your general attitude! 
 To those of you who wish to visit my country.. and the peace that we 
offer?  Welcome.  Come stay a while and enjoy our land.﻿

comments.author: FurFag49

comments.text:
Americans may live in fear and loathing of their fellow neighbours or 
citizens, but most Canadians will strike up a conversation with anyone, 
especially if they think you're from away, visiting Canada.
We'd like to know where you're from, what you think of the place, what 
sights you've seen, maybe make some sight-seeing suggestions... heck you 
might even get lucky and we buy you lunch and a beer if you're friendly 
back. You may even make new friends for a lifetime.
We don't grow up living in fear of strangers asking friendly questions as 
to whether we've been to the Stampede or not.
Small dick assholes like this American police officer Walt Wawra of 
Kalamazoo, Michigan can stay home--I'm sorry you felt threatened (and 
cowardly not having a gun by your side) by the innocent questions of 
whether you and your wife had enjoyed the sights of the Calgary Stampede.
People like you are what is wrong with this world.﻿

comments.author: Mike Hunt

comments.text: +MelioraCogito Clearly you've never been to Ottawa lol.
comments.author: Hawckey

comments.text:
+MelioraCogito, you said: "Canadian law enforcement has over the past 
decade or more decided to follow the lead of our American neighbours" Your 
fabrication. The problem was liberal style hiring as "equal opportunity 
employer". Any shit can apply.  You also said: "You're trying to paint all 
Canadians by the association of the few rotten apples found in our 
collective barrel." Isn't that the VERY substance of this whole debate?
Where is any outcry about Canadian Premier caught driving drunk in Hawaii 
endangering lives of people in another country. While here is uproar about 
what this cop just wrote to a paper. That is true hypocrisy and paranoia..
comments.author: Edward Dongres

comments.text:
+Edward Dongres wrote: "How about RCMP lying under oath about the case? Is 
it also very rare? 4) How about RCMP breaking and entering homes and 
stealing stuff? Is it also rare?"

What part of my comment: "...Canadian law enforcement has over the past 
decade or more decided to follow the lead of our American neighbours..." or 
my comment about American cultural programming exposing future [Canadian] 
law enforcement recruits to the [American] social engineering application 
of unaccountable state force, did you not understand?

I draw your attention to the news today (2015-02-18) of an Abbotsford BC 
police officer charged with corruption while 17 of his colleagues are under 
investigation for the very same criminal offence! I'm not trying to 
downplay the criminal behaviour of some [a minority] of Canada's municipal 
police or the RCMP.

You're trying to paint all Canadians by the association of the few rotten 
apples found in our collective barrel.

My original statement said: "...most Canadians will strike up a 
conversation with anyone..." which you seemed to take umbrage with.
If you would rather we be anti-social (or be viewed as anti-social or even 
sociopathic by your examples), then that is your choice, but I do not, nor 
will not be convinced that Canadians as a whole are paranoid sociopaths.
comments.author: MelioraCogito

comments.text:
+MelioraCogito, you said: "Considering the Dziekański incident at CYVR of 
which you refer was an extremely rare (and unfortunate) event, I don't get 
your point."
The points are:1) Incidents are always rare. 2) Writing to a newspaper 
reader's Column is not the same as killing someone no matter how 
politically motivated your opinion is. 3) How about RCMP lying under oath 
about the case? Is it also very rare? 4) How about RCMP breaking and 
entering homes and stealing stuff? Is it also rare?
comments.author: Edward Dongres

comments.text:
+Edward Dongres Re: teacher calling police over a child drawing a picture 
of a gun...
Again you cite a single rare incident in a nation of some 36 million 
people. Hardly conducive to a perceived epidemic of irrationalism or 
hoplophobia.
As for Canada being the "home of hoplophobes" I guess to ammosexuals who 
are I suspect biologically deficient in some other areas, that might seem 
to be the case. The majority of Canadians I would venture however do not 
grow up in a gun-loving culture. They have no real-world experience 
handling or even firing firearms. And living in a country which values the 
concept of a "civil society," far more than an armed society, we certainly 
don't see the need for citizens to be owning firearms except for the 
necessity of wilderness survival (or hunting), but that does not mean we 
wholesale deny them from doing so, so long as they can demonstrate a 
reasonable level of competency in owning, handling and storing firearms so 
they do not fall into the hands of criminals or worse, into the hands of 
children.
And before you call me a hoplophobe, I spent 15 years in the CF. And in 
that time, I have fired almost every weapon in the CF inventory from .22 
cal insert on the FN-C1, to the 105mm (106) recoilless anti-tank rifle. I 
am certainly no hoplophobe, but I also to this day have never personally 
owned a firearm, or felt the need to own one. I do not live in fear of my 
neighbours.
If I lived in the United States, exposed to its incessant social 
programming of fear & loathing, I might otherwise reconsider that necessity.
comments.author: MelioraCogito

comments.text:
+Edward Dongres
Considering the Dziekański incident at CYVR of which you refer was an 
extremely rare (and unfortunate) event, I don't get your point.
With the tens of millions of foreign nationals who enter this country from 
afar without incident every year, what happened to Robert Dziekański was a 
rare tragedy, but it is to this date the only case I am aware of - one 
single case does not define the behaviour of a nation.
I would like to think had I been there watching Mr. Dziekański, I might 
have stepped up to the plate and offered to assist him (even with the 
language barrier), before the taser-hungry RCMP arrived and dispatched him 
without even attempting to defuse the situation.
All that incident proves is that Canadian law enforcement has over the past 
decade or more decided to follow the lead of our American neighbours when 
dealing with unruly citizens/foreign nationals who are clearly in distress 
(or unable to comply with directions due to comprehension/language 
barriers). Add to that the bombardment of "American culture" such as the 
iconic social programming as FOX's COPs, which precondition potential 
police recruits to certain forms of behaviour, and I'm surprised we don't 
have more "welcome to Canada--zap!" cases like Robert Dziekański on our 
doorstep. Fact remains, we don't.
comments.author: MelioraCogito

comments.text:
+ MelioraCogito, you said: "Americans may live in fear and loathing of 
their fellow neighbours or citizens" Actually there is LOT more fear here. 
Teacher called police just because a kid draw picture of a gun. Parent had 
to be investigated. This is the home of Hoplophobes.
comments.author: Edward Dongres

comments.text:
+MelioraCogito, You said: "most Canadians will strike up a conversation 
with anyone, especially if they think you're from away, visiting Canada." 
Well, not always true. Sometime we may taser him to death even before he 
get out of the airport.
comments.author: Edward Dongres

comments.text:

comments.text:

welcome them to come and explore and visit.  DO NOT label all Americans 
with a single brush stroke based upon this one unreasonable person.  Thank 
You TYT.﻿

comments.text:
Call a guy mental is an easy way around. Because kind of leaves it to his 
past. But if this past is common occurrence among police force let's say, 
then we talk a country-wide problem. Now, regarding the police alone, the 
problem is continent-wide. I'll try my chance saying planet-no, galaxy-wide 
(stupid green midgets, still driving traffic away from Earth). Back home,

comments.text:
I think we should realize that this cop represents a very small minority of 
people in the US.

The Young Turk is an American commenting on another American.

So let's not take it as blind criticism, but an opportunity for American's 
(and Canadians) to be aware of the bad apples and start a dialogue on ways 
to improve gun safety and prevent it's abuse in the US.

There are bigger social and political pictures leading to such abusive 
attitudes.  Democracy being beaten down by corporate greed and the feeling 
that lawlessness is on the verge of fruition.

So what can Americans do to change things, return power to the people and 
have professional police officers upholding the law fairly and honourably 
for all citizens?﻿
comments.author: 123abcbruce

comments.text: Well said!
comments.author: rocker85675

comments.text:
+janie poyton, 1) why not type after you stop laughing. You have not much 
to do anyway.  
2) You don't speak for majority. Fortunately. That is why we elected, and 
re-elected Conservative government.
3) In my NW Ontario town almost all households have firearms. No crime.
4) Cancel TV cable and pick some sport or hobby. Hollywood is not real.
5) No need to lie. You said "dearth by gun in Switzerland was 45 per 
100,000" LOL, that would be 50 times higher than the actual total homicide 
rate by all means. This is what happens when you believe any BS instead 
actual statistics.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_intentional_homicide_rate
comments.author: Edward Dongres

comments.text:
+Edward Dongres
hard to type when I'm laughing but I will try to explain.....In Canada the 
majority do not want guns. We do get a lot of American tv (it is good 
entertainment) we see a lot of Americans shoot a lot of other  Americans. 
We do not want that to happen here. Some of our wantabe hoodlums live in 
cities close to the border. Apparently guns are sort of easy to smuggle 
across the borders, and they fall into nefarious hands. So we now have some 
idiots who should not own guns , having them. This brings our gun toting 
deaths up way more than we would like.Death by gun in Canada is 30.8 
per100,000  Death by gun in Switzerland was 45 per 100,000 Us 90 per 100,000
comments.author: janie poyton

comments.text:
+Edward Dongres You are twisting things.

You called people paranoid for having a fire extinguisher.

You bring up irrelevant information.  Gun is a projectile weapon and most 
laymen would call a handgun a gun or a weapon..  I'm sure you know and 
understand that, so no correction is needed.

My being more fearful of some one carrying a gun in public for self defence 
than of being robbed is obviously me stating that I have less fear of being 
robbed than of people arming themselves, it's not actually about me being 
fearful.

So, your out of context question of ["You said "how about my safety?" Yes, 
how about it? How about your safety?"] wasn't relevant to anything.
-----
Police officers have guns for self defence and to deal with criminal 
elements that may need deadly force.  That has nothing to do with the 
average citizen carrying a gun for self defence.
-----
This strategy of twisting words people say or picking on irrelevant and 
misleading points is non-sense.

The fact is we don't need to have people on the streets carrying guns for 
self defence.

You're not making any valid points.

So, I'm off.

Have a good night.
comments.author: 123abcbruce

comments.text:
+123abcbruce, you said "We don't have a gun problem". So what's your 
problem?
Btw, how do you explain Switzerland or Czech republic having lower homicide 
rate than Canada with all their lax gun laws.  Swiss have even automatic 
military "assault weapons" in their homes w/large box of ammo. Something we 
can't have.
comments.author: Edward Dongres

comments.text:
+123abcbruce, no I don't "twist things" I call is as I see it. "Whether 
appropriate to carry  gun"?  Cops and criminals do.
2) I never mentioned "weapon". Gun maybe, but I prefer the correct name 
which if firearm. Guns are on a deck of a ship. "Weapon"  is (and you can 
ask a lawyer) anything used as such. In Canada most homicides don't involve 
any firearms.
3) So you say cops have gun to take life?
comments.author: Edward Dongres

comments.text:
+Edward Dongres The point is.  This is Canada.

We don't have a gun problem.  We are all very safe and welcoming and that's 
how I would like it to stay.

Having people walk the street carrying guns for safety is nuts.

Safety from whom?  From other people carrying guns?

The streets are already safe.  Adding guns to the mix won't make it safer.
comments.author: 123abcbruce

comments.text:
+Edward Dongres You're trying to twist things.

I'm down in Toronto.  I feel perfectly safe and no one I know has a gun.

The issue isn't whether people have guns or not at home, it's whether it's 
appropriate to carry a gun in public for self defence.

Regardless we can't carry or use a gun for self defence in Canada and there 
isn't a lot of need for it.
-----
You would compare safety equipment with a weapon?  One is to protect and 
prevent loss of life the other can take a life.
-----
So having a fire extinguisher makes me paranoid?  It's a piece of safety 
equipment and I don't carry it around on the street,
comments.author: 123abcbruce

comments.text:
+123abcbruce, you said "I don't have the fear of having a life threatening 
situation that you have." Actually it's the opposite. You said "how about 
my safety?" Yes, how about it? How about your safety?
comments.author: Edward Dongres

comments.text:
+123abcbruce, 1) What makes you think I have life threatening 
situation? There's no any crime in my little town of NW Ontario. 
Practically all households have some firearms. No crime here. 
2) "inequality between rich and poor" as you put it, has nothing to do with 
freedom.
3) You don't have to wear construction helmet all the time, but you keep 
fire extinguishers in the house. How often do you have fire in the house?
4) Out pistol Gold Medal Olympian Linda Thom would very much disagree with 
your paranoia. It's called Hoplophobia. 
5) You said. "What about my right to a safe environment where no one 
carries guns?"  Who carries a gun? Criminals and cops. How do you take 
their guns away? 
6 How do you explain that I'm safe in town where almost everyone has 
some firearms?
comments.author: Edward Dongres

comments.text:
+Edward Dongres I don't have the fear of having a life threatening 
situation that you have.

I would worry more about being killed while I'm driving.

It's a matter of priorities and I don't place a lot of priority on the 
remote chance that I will get killed by someone else or need to defend 
myself with a gun.
-----
I don't like the inequality between rich and poor and to some extent yes 
big money is untouchable, however, I don't choose to let the fear of those 
problems run my life.

If a bank is robbed their policy is to co-operate with the robber, give 
them the money and call the police after.  It keeps the employees and 
customers safe.

My local bank has been robbed in the last two years and we were none the 
wiser.
-----
Regardless you could give a million scenarios where a gun may be handy or 
even save your life, however, for me it's a question of how likely is it 
and should I let fear rule my life.  My answer to that is, not very likely 
and no, I don't choose to let fear rule my life.
-----
If we had the right to open carry, I would be more worried about the guy 
with the gun than being robbed by a thief.  Someone carrying a gun who is 
walking around with the belief that he has the right to defend himself and 
that he may need to.  To me that's a far more immediate threat than the 
possibility of being robbed and killed.

What about my right to a safe environment where no one carries guns?  The 
gun carrier doesn't have rights unless other people have rights.  In Canada 
we side on the rights of everyone to feel safe in public.
-----
What if everyone walked around with a construction helmet because a plane 
might fall from the sky or everyone wore a life preserver because they 
might be swept away in a flash flood?  Yes those things are possible, but 
they are not likely and most of us choose walk around prepared for such 
situations.  The same is true of guns.  The likely hood that it will save 
your life or you will safe someone else's life is pretty remote in Canada.
comments.author: 123abcbruce

comments.text:
+123abcbruce you said:  "Money and profit come before people". That was my 
point about the banks and Brinks defence with guns. But you seems to agree 
with the imbalance in right to defend oneself. Why?
comments.author: Edward Dongres

comments.text:
+123abcbruce, you said:  "As far as I know, it is illegal to use deadly 
force to defend yourself in Canada".  Interesting. So why do you think 
police life is worth LOT more than some 80 year old pensioner? In fact 
Banks property is worth more than defenceless civilian. What happen to our 
civilization?
comments.author: Edward Dongres

comments.text:
+123abcbruce, One thing at a time. You said:  "Someone upsets you, you take 
out your cell phone and call the police." Provided you have the cell phone, 
batteries are charged, and you get the signal. The police is only minutes 
away when seconds count. So they come fast, stretched that yellow ribbon 
around your place, cover you with white sheet. Now what?
2) Why are indians demonstrating that 50 women are missing?   
3) Why are women in Toronto having "Take Back the Streets" march? 
4) Why are old folks robbed and killed in their own homes when we have 
police?
5) How many homicide victims were protected by police so far? Any?
comments.author: Edward Dongres

comments.text:
+Edward Dongres On your first point:  Someone upsets you, you take out your 
cell phone and call the police.  I don't particularly worry about being 
shot and if I'm robbed, it's only money and it can be replaced.  Why would 
one need to be protected, it is very unlikely I would ever get into a 
situation where my life was threatened.

If I were going to the woods then, maybe I would need protection from large 
animals, but I wouldn't get into a situation where I would ever meet 
someone who would threaten my life.  It's just not something I, as a 
Canadian am concerned about.

So when American's come up to Canada, you should understand there isn't the 
feeling that we need self protection.  We have police to take care of 
domestic incidences and robberies.  You're welcome to come and visit, but 
unless you're going to a slum (and I can't think of where there is one, in 
my own city) or are putting yourself into a situation where you are 
involved with drugs, just relax and enjoy yourselves!
-----
As far as I know, it is illegal to use deadly force to defend yourself in 
Canada.
-----
On your second point: Corporate greed involves paying off politicians and 
lobbyist, so they don't represent the will of the people.  Profits come 
before jobs and jobs end up being sent over-seas.  Money and profit come 
before people.

Governments lobby for free trade to appease corporations and jobs flow out 
of the country.

Your banks put the entire world into a recession in 2008 that we still 
haven't recovered from!

A lot of people around the world lost jobs, permanently and there are 
cities that have lost so much tax base that they can't balance their budget.

You end up with more crime and not enough police.

You or I being greedy wouldn't have an effect on the entire country, but 
corporate greed, treating corporations as people and other such non-sense 
that corporations have lobbied for have reduced democracy and caused a lot 
of people to have a self defence mentality instead of one of co-operation.
-----
I would say repealing corporate rights to person-hood, and re-level the 
political system to represent local people, jobs and rights.

That would alleviate a lot of issues with jobs.  States can get back to 
doing what is right for it's citizens (protecting local jobs and what is 
best for the local economy and environment instead of outside 
corporations), instead of what makes money for a cash strapped state, in 
the short term (e.g. for profit state prisons.)
comments.author: 123abcbruce

comments.text:
How EXACTLY does police protect you? Have you met homicide victim protected 
by police? 
As for politics how does "corporate greed" differ from everyone else's 
greed?

there are several reasons.

likely rat out one of your own. It is you and your brothers vs everyone

the cops that pay for it. We do in increased property taxes to pay the 
victim. It also makes the local station look bad... which leads me back to 
#1
3. This is just speculation. But I'm sure on the inside, there are 'deals' 
made about mutual protection or some bullshit for just an occasion when 
they abuse their authority and overstep their bounds. 
4. Cops are accountable to nobody and they don't have to help you. Remember 
that when you call and beg for help.

comments.text:
I'm Canadian and in my experience, Americans are friendly. This is based on 
my multiple travels to Arizona, Montana, Idaho, Washington, Oregon, and 
Hawaii. They strike up conversations everywhere I go - grocery stores, 
variety stores, gas stations, bars - more often than in Canada. Their 
curiosity about Canada is always nice. I usually give them a Loonie or a 
Twoonie ($1 and $2 Coins, respectively) and I go on with the rest of my 
travels with a smile. Just because this man in the news is bat shit crazy, 
doesn't mean he represents all Americans. Just like how these rude, 
small-minded, argumentive Canadians on this videos comment section do not 
represent me.﻿

comments.author: CF-105 Games

comments.text:
ABSOLUTELY! Don't let the comment section on YouTube paint a picture of how 
Canadians feel about Americans. We both have fucked up people walking among 
the majority of us "normal" people. I travel throughout the US and frequent 
the Alberta rockies (I live in Alberta) where TONS of Americans visit and 
have found them nothing but polite and fun to talk to. Cheers my brothers 
to the south! Lots of love from Canada..
comments.author: rocker85675

comments.text:
+CF-105 Games Like my dad used to say "The longer the Americans stay stupid 
 the better off we will be"
comments.author: Rae West

comments.text:
I have been to America and they really aren't that bad for the most part. I 
was in California for 10 days and I only encountered about 3 people in San 
Diego that were complete assholes to me because I was Canadian (they were 
in the hotel I was staying at).  Other than that, people in the US would 
ask me all kinds of silly questions about things they heard about Canada 
such as us living in igloo's and if there is snow there all the time, and 
once I explain to them how it really is they see Canada in a new light.
comments.author: CF-105 Games

comments.text: you are a nice man
comments.author: janie poyton

comments.text:
as another Canadian I have to agree, I have many friends in the USA. All of 
which are very intelligent and done nothing but shown good judgement at 
every turn. Just because this one guy is an idiot does not make an entire 
country idiots.
comments.author: Gantzz321

comments.text:
Finally a guy with some sense here :) 
I find it very interesting how people think all Americans are like this guy.
I am from Norway and I have been in both America and Canada, and I think 
both countries are very nice.

comments.text:

comments.text:

comments.text:
In Canada we do have guns, you can legally own a gun in Canada. The 
difference is we don't turn to them as an immediate solution to our 
temporary discomfort. If I was to draw a weapon each time I felt 
uncomfortable. I would have to hold the toilet paper in my left hand﻿
